    \begin{algorithm}    \caption{Quicksort}    \begin{algorithmic}    \PROCEDURE{Quicksort}{$A, p, r$}        \IF{$p < r$}             \STATE $q = $ \CALL{Partition}{$A, p, r$}            \STATE \CALL{Quicksort}{$A, p, q - 1$}            \STATE \CALL{Quicksort}{$A, q + 1, r$}        \ENDIF    \ENDPROCEDURE    \PROCEDURE{Partition}{$A, p, r$}        \STATE $x = A[r]$        \STATE $i = p - 1$        \FOR{$j = p$ \TO $r - 1$}            \IF{$A[j] < x$}                \STATE $i = i + 1$                \STATE exchange                $A[i]$ with $A[j]$            \ENDIF            \STATE exchange $A[i]$ with $A[r]$        \ENDFOR    \ENDPROCEDURE    \end{algorithmic}    \end{algorithm}

é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ æŠ€æœ¯ï¼Œå®ƒå°†ä¸¤ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªå­¦ä¹ å™¨ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚å›å½’æ¨¡å‹ã€ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œï¼‰æ¥ç”Ÿæˆæ›´å¥½çš„é¢„æµ‹ã€‚æ¢å¥è¯è¯´ï¼Œé›†æˆæ¨¡å‹å°†å¤šä¸ªå•ç‹¬çš„æ¨¡å‹ç»„åˆåœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œä»¥äº§ç”Ÿæ¯”å•ç‹¬ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¸ªæ¨¡å‹æ›´å‡†ç¡®çš„é¢„æµ‹ã€‚é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ ä¸»è¦åŒ…æ‹¬ä¸‰ç§å¸¸è§ç­–ç•¥ï¼šBaggingã€Boosting å’Œ Stackingã€‚

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä½¿ç”¨é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ 
ä½¿ç”¨é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ çš„æ ¹æœ¬åŸå› åœ¨äºå•ä¸€æ¨¡å‹å¾€å¾€å­˜åœ¨å±€é™æ€§ï¼Œå…¶é¢„æµ‹èƒ½åŠ›å¯èƒ½å—åˆ¶äºç‰¹å®šæ•°æ®åˆ†å¸ƒã€æ¨¡å‹å‡è®¾æˆ–è®­ç»ƒéšæœºæ€§ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æ³›åŒ–èƒ½åŠ›ä¸è¶³ã€‚é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ é€šè¿‡æ„å»ºå¤šä¸ªåŸºç¡€æ¨¡å‹å¹¶æ±‡æ€»ç»“æœï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨é›†ä½“æ™ºæ…§é™ä½æ•´ä½“é¢„æµ‹æ–¹å·®ã€åå·®æˆ–åŒæ—¶å‡å°‘ä¸¤è€…ï¼Œä»è€Œæå‡æ¨¡å‹è€æ“æ€§ä¸å‡†ç¡®æ€§ã€‚ä¸åŒåŸºç¡€æ¨¡å‹å¯èƒ½æ•æ‰æ•°æ®ä¸­äº’è¡¥çš„æ¨¡å¼æˆ–ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œç›¸äº’çº æ­£é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä½¿æœ€ç»ˆå†³ç­–æ›´ç¨³å®šå¯é ã€‚

Bagging

Baggingæ˜¯è‡ªåŠ©èšåˆï¼ˆBootstrap Aggregatingï¼‰çš„ç¼©å†™ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ç§é›†æˆå­¦ä¹ æŠ€æœ¯ã€‚Baggingç®—æ³•é€šè¿‡åŸºäºè‡ªåŠ©æ³•ï¼ˆBootstrap Methodï¼‰çš„é‡é‡‡æ ·æŠ€æœ¯ï¼Œä»åŸå§‹è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®é›†ä¸­æ„å»ºå¤šä¸ªäº’ä¸ç›¸åŒçš„å­è®­ç»ƒé›†ã€‚å…·ä½“è€Œè¨€ï¼Œè¯¥ç®—æ³•é‡‡ç”¨æœ‰æ”¾å›æŠ½æ ·ç­–ç•¥ï¼Œä»åŸå§‹æ•°æ®é›†ä¸­éšæœºæŠ½å–ä¸åŸæ•°æ®é›†è§„æ¨¡ç›¸ç­‰çš„æ ·æœ¬ï¼Œå½¢æˆè‡ªåŠ©æ ·æœ¬é›†ï¼ˆBootstrap Sampleï¼‰ï¼›æ­¤è¿‡ç¨‹é‡å¤å¤šæ¬¡ä»¥ç”Ÿæˆå¤šä¸ªç‹¬ç«‹çš„è‡ªåŠ©æ ·æœ¬é›†ã€‚éšåï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ªè‡ªåŠ©æ ·æœ¬é›†ä¸Šç‹¬ç«‹è®­ç»ƒä¸€ä¸ªåŸºå­¦ä¹ å™¨ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰åŸºå­¦ä¹ å™¨å‡é‡‡ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„ç®—æ³•ç±»å‹ã€‚æœ€ç»ˆï¼Œé’ˆå¯¹å›å½’ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ç®—æœ¯å¹³å‡å¯¹å¤šä¸ªåŸºå­¦ä¹ å™¨çš„é¢„æµ‹ç»“æœè¿›è¡Œèšåˆï¼›è€Œå¯¹äºåˆ†ç±»ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œåˆ™é‡‡ç”¨ç¡¬æŠ•ç¥¨æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå°†å¾—ç¥¨æ•°æœ€å¤šçš„ç±»åˆ«ä½œä¸ºæœ€ç»ˆé¢„æµ‹è¾“å‡ºã€‚
éšæœºæ£®æ—ï¼ˆRandom Forestï¼‰æ˜¯ Baggingçš„ä¸€ä¸ªç»å…¸åº”ç”¨ã€‚

éšæœºæ£®æ—

Boosting

æå‡æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆBoostingï¼‰æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥å‡å°ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ ä¸­åå·®çš„æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ç®—æ³•ã€‚ä¸»è¦ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å­¦ä¹ ä¸€ç³»åˆ—å¼±åˆ†ç±»å™¨ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶ç»„åˆä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå¼ºåˆ†ç±»å™¨ã€‚

AdaBoost

AdaBoosté€šè¿‡è°ƒæ•´æ ·æœ¬æƒé‡å’Œåˆ†ç±»å™¨æƒé‡ï¼Œä½¿æ¨¡å‹é€æ­¥èšç„¦äºéš¾ä»¥åˆ†ç±»çš„æ ·æœ¬ã€‚å…·ä½“è€Œè¨€ï¼Œåˆå§‹æ—¶æ‰€æœ‰æ ·æœ¬çš„æƒé‡ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œå³D1(i)=1nD_1(i) = \frac{1}{n}D1â€‹(i)=n1â€‹ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­nnnä¸ºæ ·æœ¬æ€»æ•°ã€‚åœ¨æ¯ä¸€è½®è¿­ä»£ä¸­ï¼Œé¦–å…ˆæ ¹æ®å½“å‰æ ·æœ¬æƒé‡è®­ç»ƒä¸€ä¸ªå¼±åˆ†ç±»å™¨ht(x)h_t(x)htâ€‹(x)ï¼Œç„¶åè®¡ç®—å…¶åŠ æƒè¯¯å·®ç‡

æ¥ç€æ ¹æ®è¯¯å·®ç‡è®¡ç®—è¯¥åˆ†ç±»å™¨çš„æƒé‡

Î±t=12logâ¡(1âˆ’ÏµtÏµt)\alpha_t = \frac{1}{2} \log\left(\frac{1 - \epsilon_t}{\epsilon_t}\right)Î±tâ€‹=21â€‹log(Ïµtâ€‹1âˆ’Ïµtâ€‹â€‹)

âˆ‚Lâˆ‚zt=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Ltâˆ‚Ltâˆ‚zt=ytâˆ’pt,t=1,2,â‹¯â€‰,Tâˆ‚Lâˆ‚rT=âˆ‚zTâˆ‚rTâˆ‚Lâˆ‚zT=âˆ‚hTâˆ‚rTâˆ‚zTâˆ‚hTâˆ‚Lâˆ‚zT=diag(Iâˆ’tanhâ¡2rT)â‹…VTâ‹…âˆ‚Lâˆ‚zTâˆ‚Lâˆ‚rt=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚rt+1âˆ‚rt+1âˆ‚rt+âˆ‚Lâˆ‚ztâˆ‚ztâˆ‚rt=âˆ‚htâˆ‚rt(âˆ‚rt+1âˆ‚htâˆ‚Lâˆ‚rt+1+âˆ‚ztâˆ‚htâˆ‚Lâˆ‚zt)\begin{align}\frac{\partial L}{\partial z_t} & = \frac{\partial L}{\partial L_t} \frac{\partial L_t}{\partial z_t} = y_t - p_t, \quad t = 1, 2, \cdots, T \\\frac{\partial L}{\partial r_T} & = \frac{\partial z_T}{\partial r_T} \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_T} = \frac{\partial h_T}{\partial r_T} \frac{\partial z_T}{\partial h_T} \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_T} = \text{diag}\left( I - \tanh^2 r_T \right) \cdot V^T \cdot \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_T} \\\frac{\partial L}{\partial r_t} & = \frac{\partial L}{\partial r_{t+1}} \frac{\partial r_{t+1}}{\partial r_t} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_t} \frac{\partial z_t}{\partial r_t} = \frac{\partial h_t}{\partial r_t} \left( \frac{\partial r_{t+1}}{\partial h_t} \frac{\partial L}{\partial r_{t+1}} + \frac{\partial z_t}{\partial h_t} \frac{\partial L}{\partial z_t} \right)\end{align}âˆ‚ztâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹âˆ‚rTâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹âˆ‚rtâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹â€‹=âˆ‚Ltâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹âˆ‚ztâ€‹âˆ‚Ltâ€‹â€‹=ytâ€‹âˆ’ptâ€‹,t=1,2,â‹¯,T=âˆ‚rTâ€‹âˆ‚zTâ€‹â€‹âˆ‚zTâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹=âˆ‚rTâ€‹âˆ‚hTâ€‹â€‹âˆ‚hTâ€‹âˆ‚zTâ€‹â€‹âˆ‚zTâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹=diag(Iâˆ’tanh2rTâ€‹)â‹…VTâ‹…âˆ‚zTâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹=âˆ‚rt+1â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹âˆ‚rtâ€‹âˆ‚rt+1â€‹â€‹+âˆ‚ztâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹âˆ‚rtâ€‹âˆ‚ztâ€‹â€‹=âˆ‚rtâ€‹âˆ‚htâ€‹â€‹(âˆ‚htâ€‹âˆ‚rt+1â€‹â€‹âˆ‚rt+1â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹+âˆ‚htâ€‹âˆ‚ztâ€‹â€‹âˆ‚ztâ€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹)â€‹â€‹

\begin{algorithm}\caption{éçº¿æ€§æ”¯æŒå‘é‡æœº}\begin{algorithmic}\STATE \textbf{è¾“å…¥ï¼š} è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®é›† $T = \{(x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), \cdots, (x_N, y_N)\}$ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ $x_i \in \mathcal{X} = \mathbb{R}^n$ï¼Œ$y_i \in \mathcal{Y} = \{-1, +1\}$ï¼Œ$i = 1, 2, \cdots, N$\STATE \textbf{è¾“å‡ºï¼š} åˆ†ç±»å†³ç­–å‡½æ•°\STATE \textbf{æ­¥éª¤1ï¼šæ„é€ å¹¶æ±‚è§£ä¼˜åŒ–é—®é¢˜}\STATE é€‰å–æ ¸å‡½æ•° $K(x, z)$ å’Œæ­£åˆ™åŒ–å‚æ•° $C$\STATE æ±‚è§£ä»¥ä¸‹å‡¸äºŒæ¬¡è§„åˆ’é—®é¢˜ï¼š\\$\min_{\alpha} \quad \dfrac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \alpha_i \alpha_j y_i y_j K(x_i, x_j) - \sum_{i=1}^{N} \alpha_i$ \\$\text{s.t. } \quad \sum_{i=1}^{N} \alpha_i y_i = 0$ï¼Œ$0 \leq \alpha_i \leq C$ï¼Œ$i = 1, 2, \cdots, N$ \\æ±‚å¾—æœ€ä¼˜è§£ $\alpha^* = (\alpha_1^*, \alpha_2^*, \cdots, \alpha_N^*)^{\top}$\STATE \textbf{æ­¥éª¤2ï¼šè®¡ç®—åç½®é¡¹ $b^*$}\STATE é€‰æ‹©æ»¡è¶³ $0 < \alpha_j^* < C$ çš„åˆ†é‡ $\alpha_j^*$\STATE è®¡ç®—ï¼š$b^* = y_j - \sum_{i=1}^{N} \alpha_i^* y_i K(x_i, x_j)$\STATE \textbf{æ­¥éª¤3ï¼šæ„é€ å†³ç­–å‡½æ•°}\STATE åˆ†ç±»å†³ç­–å‡½æ•°ï¼š$f(x) = \mathrm{sign} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{N} \alpha_i^* y_i K(x, x_i) + b^* \right)$\STATE \textbf{è¿”å›} åˆ†ç±»å†³ç­–å‡½æ•° $f(x)$\end{algorithmic}\end{algorithm}

\begin{algorithm}\caption{å±‚æ¬¡èšç±»}\begin{algorithmic}\REQUIRE æ ·æœ¬é›†åˆ $X = \{ x_1, x_2, \cdots, x_n \}$ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ $x_i \in \mathbb{R}^m$ï¼›æ ·æœ¬é—´è·ç¦»åº¦é‡\ENSURE æ ·æœ¬é›†åˆçš„å±‚æ¬¡åŒ–èšç±»ç»“æ„\STATE è®¡ç®—æ‰€æœ‰æ ·æœ¬ä¸¤ä¸¤ä¹‹é—´çš„æ¬§æ°è·ç¦»ï¼š$d_{ij} = \| x_i - x_j \|_2$ï¼Œæ„å»ºè·ç¦»çŸ©é˜µ $D = [d_{ij}]_{n \times n}$\STATE åˆ›å»º $n$ ä¸ªåˆå§‹ç±»ï¼š$C_i = \{x_i\}, \quad i = 1, 2, \cdots, n$\WHILE{ç±»çš„ä¸ªæ•° > 1}    \STATE æ‰¾åˆ°è·ç¦»æœ€å°çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªç±»ï¼š$(C_p, C_q) = \arg\min_{i < j} d(C_i, C_j)$    \STATE åˆå¹¶è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªç±»ï¼Œå½¢æˆæ–°ç±»ï¼š$C_{\text{new}} = C_p \cup C_q$    \STATE ä»å½“å‰ç±»é›†åˆä¸­ç§»é™¤ $C_p$ å’Œ $C_q$ï¼ŒåŠ å…¥ $C_{\text{new}}$    \STATE æ›´æ–°è·ç¦»çŸ©é˜µï¼šè®¡ç®— $C_{\text{new}}$ ä¸å…¶ä½™å„ç±»çš„è·ç¦»ï¼ˆä½¿ç”¨æœ€çŸ­è·ç¦»/å•é“¾æ³•ï¼‰\ENDWHILE\STATE \textbf{è¿”å›} æ ·æœ¬é›†åˆçš„å±‚æ¬¡åŒ–èšç±»\end{algorithmic}\end{algorithm}

    aij(n+1)=âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ’1Î¾t(i,j)âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ’1Î³t(i)bj(n+1)(k)=âˆ‘t=1,ot=vkTÎ³t(j)âˆ‘t=1TÎ³t(j)Ï€i(n+1)=Î³1(i) \begin{align*} a_{ij}^{(n+1)} &= \frac{\sum_{t=1}^{T-1} \xi_t(i,j)}{\sum_{t=1}^{T-1} \gamma_t(i)} \\ b_j^{(n+1)}(k) &= \frac{\sum_{t=1, o_t=v_k}^T \gamma_t(j)}{\sum_{t=1}^T \gamma_t(j)} \\ \pi_i^{(n+1)} &= \gamma_1(i)\end{align*} aij(n+1)â€‹bj(n+1)â€‹(k)Ï€i(n+1)â€‹â€‹=âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ’1â€‹Î³tâ€‹(i)âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ’1â€‹Î¾tâ€‹(i,j)â€‹=âˆ‘t=1Tâ€‹Î³tâ€‹(j)âˆ‘t=1,otâ€‹=vkâ€‹Tâ€‹Î³tâ€‹(j)â€‹=Î³1â€‹(i)â€‹

  2. é€’æ¨ (t=2t=2t=2 åˆ° TTT):

å¯¹äºæœ‰nnnä¸ªå˜é‡x1,x2,â€¦,xnx_{1},x_{2},\dots,x_{n}x1â€‹,x2â€‹,â€¦,xnâ€‹çš„å‡½æ•°fffï¼Œå®šä¹‰åå¯¼æ•°

âˆ‚fâˆ‚xi=limâ¡hâ†’0f(x1,â€¦,xi+h,â€¦,xn)âˆ’f(x)h\begin{align}\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{i}} = \lim_{ h \to 0 }\frac{f(x_{1},\dots,x_{i}+h,\dots,x_{n}) - f(\boldsymbol{x})}{h}\end{align}âˆ‚xiâ€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹=hâ†’0limâ€‹hf(x1â€‹,â€¦,xiâ€‹+h,â€¦,xnâ€‹)âˆ’f(x)â€‹â€‹â€‹

â–½xf=grad f=[âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1,âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2,â€¦,âˆ‚fâˆ‚xn]\begin{align}\triangledown_{\boldsymbol{x}} f = \text{grad} \ f = \left[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{1}},\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{2}},\dots,\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{n}} \right]\end{align}â–½xâ€‹f=grad f=[âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,â€¦,âˆ‚xnâ€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹]â€‹â€‹

è€ƒè™‘ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ x1,x2x_1, x_2x1â€‹,x2â€‹ çš„å‡½æ•° f:R2â†’Rf: \mathbb{R}^2 \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:R2â†’Rã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œx1(t)x_1(t)x1â€‹(t) å’Œ x2(t)x_2(t)x2â€‹(t) æœ¬èº«å°±æ˜¯ ttt çš„å‡½æ•°ã€‚ä¸ºäº†è®¡ç®— fff ç›¸å¯¹äº ttt çš„æ¢¯åº¦ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å¯¹å¤šå…ƒå‡½æ•°ä½¿ç”¨é“¾å¼æ³•åˆ™ï¼š

dfdt=[âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2][âˆ‚x1(t)âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2(t)âˆ‚t]=âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚x1âˆ‚t+âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2âˆ‚x2âˆ‚t\begin{align}\frac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}t} = \begin{bmatrix}\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} & \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\frac{\partial x_1(t)}{\partial t} \\\frac{\partial x_2(t)}{\partial t}\end{bmatrix}= \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t}\end{align}dtdfâ€‹=[âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹â€‹âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹â€‹][âˆ‚tâˆ‚x1â€‹(t)â€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2â€‹(t)â€‹â€‹]=âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x1â€‹â€‹+âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

å¦‚æœ f(x1,x2)f(x_1, x_2)f(x1â€‹,x2â€‹) æ˜¯ x1x_1x1â€‹ å’Œ x2x_2x2â€‹ çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ x1(s,t)x_1(s, t)x1â€‹(s,t) å’Œ x2(s,t)x_2(s, t)x2â€‹(s,t) æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªå˜é‡ sss å’Œ ttt çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œåˆ™ç”¨é“¾å¼æ³•åˆ™æ±‚å¾—åå¯¼æ•°ä¸ºï¼š

âˆ‚fâˆ‚s=âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚x1âˆ‚s+âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2âˆ‚x2âˆ‚s\frac{\partial f}{\partial s} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial s} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial s}âˆ‚sâˆ‚fâ€‹=âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚sâˆ‚x1â€‹â€‹+âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚sâˆ‚x2â€‹â€‹

âˆ‚fâˆ‚t=âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚x1âˆ‚t+âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2âˆ‚x2âˆ‚t\frac{\partial f}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t}âˆ‚tâˆ‚fâ€‹=âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x1â€‹â€‹+âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2â€‹â€‹

æ¢¯åº¦ç”±çŸ©é˜µç›¸ä¹˜å¾—åˆ°

dfd(s,t)=âˆ‚fâˆ‚xâˆ‚xâˆ‚(s,t)=[âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2]âŸâˆ‚fâˆ‚x[âˆ‚x1âˆ‚sâˆ‚x1âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2âˆ‚sâˆ‚x2âˆ‚t]âŸâˆ‚xâˆ‚(s,t)\begin{aligned}\frac{df}{d(s,t)} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial \boldsymbol{x}} \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{x}}{\partial (s,t)} = \underbrace{\left[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \quad \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \right]}_{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \boldsymbol{x}}}\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}\frac{\partial x_1}{\partial s} & \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t} \\\frac{\partial x_2}{\partial s} & \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t}\end{bmatrix}}_{\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{x}}{\partial (s,t)}}\end{aligned}d(s,t)dfâ€‹=âˆ‚xâˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚(s,t)âˆ‚xâ€‹=âˆ‚xâˆ‚fâ€‹[âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹âˆ‚x2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹]â€‹â€‹âˆ‚(s,t)âˆ‚xâ€‹[âˆ‚sâˆ‚x1â€‹â€‹âˆ‚sâˆ‚x2â€‹â€‹â€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x1â€‹â€‹âˆ‚tâˆ‚x2â€‹â€‹â€‹]â€‹â€‹â€‹

å‘é‡å€¼å‡½æ•°çš„æ¢¯åº¦

å‡½æ•° f:Rnâ†’Rmf: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^mf:Rnâ†’Rm ç›¸å¯¹äº xâˆˆRn\boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^nxâˆˆRn çš„æ¢¯åº¦ï¼š

df(x)dx=[âˆ‚f(x)âˆ‚x1â‹¯âˆ‚f(x)âˆ‚xn]=[âˆ‚f1(x)âˆ‚x1â‹¯âˆ‚f1(x)âˆ‚xnâ‹®â‹®âˆ‚fm(x)âˆ‚x1â‹¯âˆ‚fm(x)âˆ‚xn]âˆˆRmÃ—n.\begin{equation}\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{x}} &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_n} \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{ccc} \frac{\partial f_1(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_1(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_n} \\ \vdots & & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial f_m(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_m(\boldsymbol{x})}{\partial x_n} \end{array}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}. \end{aligned}\end{equation}dxdf(x)â€‹â€‹=[âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚f(x)â€‹â€‹â‹¯â€‹âˆ‚xnâ€‹âˆ‚f(x)â€‹â€‹]=â€‹âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚f1â€‹(x)â€‹â‹®âˆ‚x1â€‹âˆ‚fmâ€‹(x)â€‹â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â€‹âˆ‚xnâ€‹âˆ‚f1â€‹(x)â€‹â‹®âˆ‚xnâ€‹âˆ‚fmâ€‹(x)â€‹â€‹â€‹âˆˆRmÃ—n.â€‹â€‹â€‹

entry.title: ML#0.2 Getting Started with pandas
entry.content:
[!NOTE] æ³¨æ„
æœ¬ç« å¤§ç¯‡å¹…å¼•ç”¨Pyhon for Data Analysis,Third Edition,Wes McKinneyï¼Œä»…ä½œä¸ºå­¦ä¹ äº¤æµä½¿ç”¨ã€‚

æœ¬ç« é»˜è®¤è¿›è¡Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ“ä½œï¼š

import numpy as np

import pandas as pd

Getting Started with pandas

pandas Data Structures

Series

The string representation of a Series displayed interactively
shows the index on the left and the values on the right.

Using NumPy functions or NumPy-like operations,
such as filtering with a Boolean array, scalar
multiplication, or applying math functions
, will preserve the index-value link.

DataFrame

The del keyword will delete columns like with a dictionary.

Possible data inputs to the DataFrame constructor

TypeNotes
2D ndarrayA matrix of data, passing optional row and column labels
Dictionary of arrays, lists, or tuplesEach sequence becomes a column in the DataFrame; all sequences must be the same length
NumPy structured/record arrayTreated as the â€œdictionary of arraysâ€ case
Dictionary of SeriesEach value becomes a column; indexes from each Series are unioned together to form the resultâ€™s row index if no explicit index is passed
Dictionary of dictionariesEach inner dictionary becomes a column; keys are unioned to form the row index as in the â€œdictionary of Seriesâ€ case
List of dictionaries or SeriesEach item becomes a row in the DataFrame; unions of dictionary keys or Series indexes become the DataFrameâ€™s column labels
List of lists or tuplesTreated as the â€œ2D ndarrayâ€ case
Another DataFrameThe DataFrameâ€™s indexes are used unless different ones are passed
NumPy MaskedArrayLike the â€œ2D ndarrayâ€ case except masked values are missing in the DataFrame result

Some Index methods and properties

Method/PropertyDescription
append()Concatenate with additional Index objects, producing a new Index
difference()Compute set difference as an Index
intersection()Compute set intersection
union()Compute set union
isin()Compute Boolean array indicating whether each value is contained in the passed collection
delete()Compute new Index with element at Index i deleted
drop()Compute new Index by deleting passed values
insert()Compute new Index by inserting element at Index i
is_monotonicReturns True if each element is greater than or equal to the previous element
is_uniqueReturns True if the Index has no duplicate values
unique()Compute the array of unique values in the Index

Essential Functionality

Reindex

Dropping Entries from an Axis

DataFrame.drop(labels=None, *, axis=0, index=None, columns=None, level=None, inplace=False, errors='raise')

Parameters:

  • labels
    single label or list-like
    Index labels to drop.

  • axis
    {0 or â€˜indexâ€™}
    Unused. Parameter needed for compatibility with DataFrame.

  • index
    single label or list-like
    Redundant for application on Series, but â€˜indexâ€™ can be used instead of â€˜labelsâ€™.

  • columns
    single label or list-like
    No change is made to the Series; use â€˜indexâ€™ or â€˜labelsâ€™ instead.

  • level
    int or level name, optional
    For MultiIndex, level for which the labels will be removed.

  • inplace
    bool, default False
    If True, do operation inplace and return None.

  • errors
    {â€˜ignoreâ€™, â€˜raiseâ€™}, default â€˜raiseâ€™
    If â€˜ignoreâ€™, suppress error and only existing labels are dropped.

Series.drop(labels=None, *, axis=0, index=None, columns=None, level=None, inplace=False, errors='raise')

Parameters:

  • labels
    array-like, optional
    New labels/index to conform the axis specified by â€˜axisâ€™ to.

  • index
    array-like, optional
    New labels for the index. Preferably an Index object to avoid duplicating data.

  • columns
    array-like, optional
    New labels for the columns. Preferably an Index object to avoid duplicating data.

  • axis
    int or str, optional
    Axis to target. Can be either the axis name (â€˜indexâ€™, â€˜columnsâ€™) or number (0, 1).

  • method
    {None, â€˜backfillâ€™/â€˜bfillâ€™, â€˜padâ€™/â€˜ffillâ€™, â€˜nearestâ€™}
    Method to use for filling holes in reindexed DataFrame.

    • None (default): Donâ€™t fill gaps.
    • pad / ffill: Propagate last valid observation forward to next valid.
    • backfill / bfill: Use next valid observation to fill gap.
    • nearest: Use nearest valid observations to fill gap.

  • copy
    bool, default True
    Return a new object, even if the passed indexes are the same.

  • level
    int or name
    Broadcast across a level, matching Index values on the passed MultiIndex level.

  • fill_value
    scalar, default np.nan
    Value to use for missing values. Defaults to NaN, but can be any compatible value.

  • limit
    int, default None
    Maximum number of consecutive elements to forward or backward fill.

  • tolerance
    optional
    Maximum distance between original and new labels for inexact matches. Can be scalar or list-like, applying variable tolerance per element.

Indexing, Selection, and Filtering

Since loc operator indexes exclusively with labels, there is also an iloc operator that indexes exclusively with integers to work consistently whether or not the index contains integers.

Indexing options with DataFrame

Arithmetic and Data Alignment

MethodDescription
add, raddMethods for addition (+)
sub, rsubMethods for subtraction (-)
div, rdivMethods for division (/)
floordiv, rfloordivMethods for floor division (//)
mul, rmulMethods for multiplication (*)
pow, rpowMethods for exponentiation (**)

Sorting and Ranking

Table: Tie-breaking methods with rank

MethodDescription
"average"Default: assign the average rank to each entry in the equal group
"min"Use the minimum rank for the whole group
"max"Use the maximum rank for the whole group
"first"Assign ranks in the order the values appear in the data
"dense"Like method=â€œminâ€, but ranks always increase by 1 between groups rather than the number of equal elements in a group

Summarizing and Computing Descriptive Statistics

Table:Descriptive and summary statistics

MethodDescription
countNumber of non-NA values
describeCompute set of summary statistics
min, maxCompute minimum and maximum values
argmin, argmaxCompute index locations (integers) at which minimum or maximum value is obtained; not available on DataFrame objects
idxmin, idxmaxCompute index labels at which minimum or maximum value is obtained
quantileCompute sample quantile ranging from 0 to 1 (default: 0.5)
sumSum of values
meanMean of values
medianArithmetic median (50% quantile) of values
madMean absolute deviation from mean value
prodProduct of all values
varSample variance of values
stdSample standard deviation of values
skewSample skewness (third moment) of values
kurtSample kurtosis (fourth moment) of values
cumsumCumulative sum of values
cummin, cummaxCumulative minimum or maximum of values, respectively
cumprodCumulative product of values
diffCompute first arithmetic difference (useful for time series)
pct_changeCompute percent changes

Table: Options for reduction methods

MethodDescription
axisAxis to reduce over; â€œindexâ€ for DataFrameâ€™s rows and â€œcolumnsâ€ for columns
skipnaExclude missing values; True by default
levelReduce grouped by level if the axis is hierarchically indexed (MultiIndex)

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

NumPy Basics: Arrays and Vectorized Computation

NumPy, short for Numerical Python, is one of the most important foundational packages for numerical computing in Python.

The NumPy ndarray: A Multidimensional Array Object

Creating ndarrays:arr1 = np.array(data1)

0s,1s,Trues:

Data Types for ndarrays

Indexing and Slicing

Boolean Indexing

Fancy Indexing

Pseudorandom Number Generation

å¼•ç”¨è‡ª:NumPy random number generator methods

Numpy.Random API reference:https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/random/index.html

MethodDescription
permutationReturn a random permutation of a sequence, or return a permuted range
shuffleRandomly permute a sequence in place
uniformDraw samples from a uniform distribution
integersDraw random integers from a given low-to-high range
standard_normalDraw samples from a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1
binomialDraw samples from a binomial distribution
normalDraw samples from a normal (Gaussian) distribution
betaDraw samples from a beta distribution
chisquareDraw samples from a chi-square distribution
gammaDraw samples from a gamma distribution
uniformDraw samples from a uniform [0, 1) distribution

Universal Functions
